DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Rejects Calls Against Marxist-Leninist Dictatorship
DOC.TEXT: The ruling party Friday ignored calls to heed the collapse of Communism in eastern Europe and pledged to create a one-party Marxist-Leninist state. The decision, on the final day of the four-day Patriotic Front congress, was contained in a document approved by 4,200 delegates. It restated the dream of President Robert Mugabe to transform one of Africa's few Western-style democracies into a single-party nation, which he may do next year. The party's aim is ``to establish and sustain a socialist society guided by Marxist-Leninist principles but firmly based on our historical, cultural and social experience and to create conditions for economic independence, increased productivity and equitable distribution of the wealth of the nation,'' it said. Mugabe, who led the former white-ruled British colony of Rhodesia to independence as black-governed Zimbabwe on April 18, 1980, strenuously urged delegates to reject calls to abandon this goal in favor of multiparty democracy and a free enterprise economy. The debate behind closed doors was ``heated but healthy,'' said party spokesman Nathan Shamuyarira, who is also minister of foreign affairs. Pro-democracy groups had hoped Zimbabwe would follow some other African states that abandoned radical leftist policies in line with events in eastern Europe. In Benin, a former French territory in West Africa, the leadership early this month denounced Communism and promised constitutional reforms. In Ethiopia, Africa's most rigid Marxist state, President Mengistu Haile Mariam has been forced to hold peace talks with guerrilla chieftains since the Soviet Union began reducing military supplies to fight secessionist wars. This has raised the prospect he might pursue political liberalization. More and more African countries also are jettisoning outdated economic policies in favor of reforms proposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. In recent months, as pro-democratic movements have swept eastern Europe, Mugabe has come under pressure to abandon the aim of a one-party state. Mugabe's Patriotic Front has been avowedly Marxist-Leninist since independence. Former opposition leader Joshua Nkomo was more centrist. But the two decided two years ago to merge forces, a move that was formalized by their first joint congress this week. The ruling party can pass laws and rewrite sections of the British-drafted constitution, a document signed by all parties 10 years ago. Those constitutional talks ended nine decades of white minority rule, halted a seven-year war waged by guerrillas loyal to Nkomo and Mugabe, and steered Zimbabwe to independence. The constitution guaranteed Zimbabwe would be a multi-party democracy for the first 10 years of independence. After the 10th anniversary, Mugabe may ban opposition and establish a single-party state with two-thirds of the votes in Parliament.
